review.title: Know-Evolve: Deep Temporal Reasoning for Dynamic Knowledge Graphs
review.abstract: Knowledge Graphs are important tools to model multi-relational data that serves as information pool for various applications. Traditionally, these graphs are considered to be static in nature. However, recent availability of large scale event-based interaction data has given rise to dynamically evolving knowledge graphs that contain temporal information for each edge. Reasoning over time in such graphs is not yet well understood.

metadata.title: Know-Evolve: Deep Reasoning in Temporal Knowledge Graphs

sections.text: In this paper, we present a novel, in-depth evolutionary knowledge network architecture to learn the embedding of units that can evolve dynamically and nonlinearly over time. We also propose a framework for a multivariate point process to model the occurrence of a fact (edge) in continuous time. To facilitate temporal thinking, the learned embedding is used to calculate a relationship value that further parameterizes the intensity function of the point process. We demonstrate improved performance over various existing relational learning models on two large real-world datasets. Furthermore, our method effectively predicts the occurrence or recurrence of a fact that is new compared to previous argumentation approaches in multirelational environments.

sections.heading: 2. Preliminaries
sections.text: We provide necessary background information on time processes and temporal knowledge graphs.

sections.heading: 2.1. Temporal Point Process
sections.text: A point-of-time process (Cox & Lewis, 2006) is a random process whose realization consists of a list of events located in time, {ti} with ti-R +. Equivalent, a given point-of-time process can be represented as a counting process, N (t), which records the number of events before time. An important method for characterizing point-of-time processes is the conditional intensity function λ (t), a stochastic model for the time of the next event that shows all previous events. Formally, λ (t) dt is the conditional probability of observing an event in a small window [t, t + dt) given the history T (t): = {tk | tk < t} to t, i.e., λ (t) dt: = P {event in [t, t + dt) | T (t)}} = probability (t) = E [dN (t) | T (t)]]] (1), typically assuming that a window is a small one, i.e.

sections.heading: 2.2. Temporal Knowledge Graph representation
sections.text: We define a time-limited knowledge graph (TKG) as a multirelational graph with timed edges between arbitrary node pairs and can consider it as a dynamic counterpart to the static knowledge graphs described above. In TKG, each edge between two nodes represents an event in the real world between two entities and the edge type (relationship) the corresponding event type. Furthermore, an edge may or may not exist multiple times (repetition). We do not allow double edges and self-loops in the graph. Therefore, all recurring edges will have different time points and each edge will have different subject and object titles.Given individual entities and nr relationships, we expand the traditional triplet representation for knowledge graphs to introduce the time dimension and represent each fact in TKG as a quadrangular (es, r, eo, t).

sections.heading: 3. Evolutionary Knowledge Network
sections.text: The reasoning power of Know-Evolve rests on three main components of the Evolutionary Knowledge Network: 1. A powerful mathematical tool of the point-of-time process that models the occurrence of a fact; 2. A bilinear relational value that captures multirelational interactions between units and parameterizes the intensity function of the process described above; 3. A novel, deeply recurring network that dynamically and reciprocally learns latent representations of units based on their interactions with other units in multirelational space over time.

sections.heading: 3.1. Temporal Process
sections.text: Large temporal knowledge diagrams show highly heterogeneous temporal patterns of events between different units. As these units coevolve nonlinearly, they complement the complex temporal dependencies. Individual epoch-based methods have been widely used to model temporal behavior in different environments with interaction data, but these methods fail to grasp the complex temporal dependencies underlying them. Therefore, we model time as a random variable and use temporal point processes to model the occurrence of factors. Specifically, in the face of a series of observed events O, which correspond to a TKG, we construct a relationship-modulated multidimensional point process to model the occurrence of these events. We characterize this point process with the following conditional intensity function: p, eo r (t | t) = f (ge s, eo r (t))) = f (t (t (t)))), eo (t (t), t), (t), (t), (t), (t), (t), (t), (t), (t), (t), (t), or (t) the event prior to the time (t).

sections.heading: 3.2. Relational Score Function
sections.text: The first term in (3) modulates the intensity function by the relational compatibility score between the entities involved in this specific relationship. Specifically, the score term ges, eor is calculated using a bilinear formulation as follows: ge s, eo r (t) = v es (t −) T · Rr · ve o (t −) (4), where ve s, ve s ² Rd represent latent feature embeddings of entities that appear in subject or object position, respectively. Rr ² Rd · d represents a relationship weight matrix that attempts to capture the interaction between two entities in the specific relationship space r. This matrix is unique for each relationship in the dataset and is learned during the training. Rr ² Rd · d represents the time of the current event and t − represent a time just before time. ve (t −) and veo () − therefore represent the objects of these vector dynamics before being incorporated into the time.

sections.heading: 3.4. Understanding Unified View of Know-Evolve
sections.text: Figure (2) and Figure (3) show the architecture of the knowledge development framework and a complete step of our model. We offer a summary of all the notations in the appendix. The updates of the entity representations in Equation (5) and (6) are driven by the events related to those entities that make the embedding constant bit by bit, i.e. an entity remains unchanged in the duration between two events affecting that entity and is only updated when an event occurs in its dimension. This is justified because the properties of an entity can only be updated if it forges a relationship with other entities within the diagram. Note that the first term in Equation (5) and (6) already takes external influences into account. After observing an event in due course, Know-Evolve considers it as a fact that generates new knowledge of the entities involved in that event within the diagram.

sections.heading: 5. Experiments
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1. Temporal Knowledge Graph Data
sections.text: We use two sets of data - Global Database of Events, Language, and Tone (GDELT) (Leetaru & Schrodt, 2013) and Integrated Crisis Early Warning System (ICEWS) (Boschee et al., 2017), which have recently been noted as useful temporal KGs in the learning community (Schein et al., 2016). GDELT data is collected from April 1, 2015 to March 31, 2016 (temporal granularity of 15 minutes); ICEWS data is collected from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014 (temporal granularity of 24 hours); both sets of data contain recordings of events involving actors, event-related actions and timestamps of the event; and we use different hierarchies of actions in two sets of data - (top-level 20 relationships for GDELT, while the last level 260 relationships for ICEWS) - to test the diversity of knowledge locations or configurations.

sections.heading: 5.2. Competitors
sections.text: We compare the performance of our method with the following methods of relational learning: RESCAL, Neural Tensor Network (NTN), Multiway Neural Network, TransE and TransR. To our knowledge, there are no existing approaches to relational learning that can predict the time for a new fact. Therefore, we have developed two basic methods for assessing time prediction performance: Multidimensional Hawkes Process (MHP): We model dynamic interactions between entities as a multidimensional Hawkes process similar to (Du et al., 2015). Here, an entity pair represents a dimension, and for each pair we collect event sequences on its dimension and train and test on that sequence. Relationships are not modeled in this sequence. Recurring Temporal Point Process (RTPP): We implement a simplified version of RMTPP (Du et al., 2016) in which we do not predict the marker.

sections.heading: 5.3. Evaluation metric
sections.text: We report experimental results on two tasks: link prediction and time prediction. Link prediction: Faced with a test quadruple (es, r, eo, t), we replace eo with all entities in the dataset and calculate the conditional density de s, eor = λ es, eo r (t) S es, eor (t) for the resulting quadruplets including soil truth. We then sort the quadruplets in descending order of that density to rank the correct entity for the object position. This procedure can be calculated symmetrically for subject and object. Next, we perform tests after applying the filter techniques described in (Bordes et al., 2013) - we only rank against entities that do not produce real triplets (seen in train) when replacing the basic truth object. We report Mean Average Rank, standard deviation for test samples over the top 10 and HITS @ correctness.

sections.heading: 5.4. Quantitative Analysis
sections.text: In fact, it is that we are able to assert ourselves, that we are able to comply, that we are able to comply with the rules, and that we are able to comply with the rules that we have set ourselves.

sections.heading: 6. Related Work
sections.text: In this section, we discuss relevant work in the field of relational learning and current work that takes temporal characteristics into account in relational data.

sections.heading: 6.1. Relational Learning
sections.text: Among the various relational learning methods that focus on learning low-dimensional representations of entities and relationships is the performance of the state. Specifically, these methods are embedded in a low-dimensional continuous vector space and an evaluation is made for the fact that is based on different operations of these new representations. To learn these representations, either logistical losses or paired ranking losses must be minimized using stochastic gradient algorithms (Nickel et al., 2016a). Such models can be mainly categorized into two variants: compositional models such as RESCAL or paired ranking losses. Nickel et al., 2011) and Neural Tensor Network Descent Algorithms (Nickel et al., 2013), we use tensor product-specific interactions between entities and relationships that represent a specific weight matrix to explain triplexes.

sections.heading: 6.2. Temporal features in relational models
sections.text: Recently (Esteban et al., 2016), the authors proposed a multi-path neural network-based model for the task of event forecasting in event-based relational graphs. In this paper, the authors establish a synergistic relationship between a static knowledge graph and an event set based on this graph, with the knowledge graph providing information about units participating in events and new events, which in turn contribute to improving the knowledge graph. They do not capture the evolving dynamics of units. In addition, they model time as individual points and adopt a time series-based approach that limits the ability to model complex temporal dynamics. (Jiang et al., 2016) suggests a method for time-conscious link forecasting, but they model the dependence of the relationship to time.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: We propose a profound new type of evolutionary knowledge network that can efficiently learn dynamically evolving entity-embeddings and grasp complicated temporal dependencies in a multirelational environment. We demonstrate the evolutionary dynamics of both subjects and object-entities through a deep, recurring neural network that learns from the historical evolution of entity-embeddings in a particular relationship space. We demonstrate the superior performance and high scalability of our method through extensive experiments with large real-world event graphs. Therefore, it confirms the importance of modelling temporal dynamics in dynamically evolving relationship processes. Our model establishes a previously unexplored link between relational processes and time-point processes and it has the potential to open up a new direction of exploration of thinking over time.

sections.heading: A. Algorithm for Global BPTT Computation
sections.text: Algorithm 2 Global-BPTT Input: Global Event Sequence O, Steps s, Stopping Condition max iter cur index = 0, t begin = 0 for iter = 0 to max iter doif cur index > 0 then t begin = O [cur index − 1] → t end if e mini batch = O [cur index: cur index + s] Build Training Network specific to e mini batch Feed Forward inputs over network of s time steps Compute Total Loss L over s steps: L = − s p = 1 log (λe, eo r (tp | t p)) + Survival loss computered using Algorithm 1 Backpropagate error through s time steps and update all weights if cur index + s > O.size then cur index = 0 other cur index = cur index + send if end for

sections.heading: B. Data Statistics and Sparsity of Knowledge Tensor
sections.text: Table 3. Sparsity of Knowledge Tensor.Dataset Name # Possible # Available% Proportion EnttriesGDELT-full 3.93B 4.52M 0.12 GDELT-500 5M 0.76M 15.21 ICEWS-full 39.98B 0.31M 7e-3 ICEWS-500 64M 0.15M 0.24C. Implementation Details Know-Evolve. Both Algorithm 1 and Algorithm 2 show that the computational graph will be significantly different for each mini-batch, as the interactions in each window vary greatly. To facilitate efficient training on dynamic computation diagram settings, we use the embedding system proposed in (Dai et al., 2016), which allows us to learn about the graph structure, in which the objective function can have potentially different computation diagrams for each batch. We use Adam Optimizer with gradient cutouts for parameters updates. With the help of the search parameter, we set a minimum parameter for each hynamics parameter.

sections.heading: D. Exploratory Analysis
sections.text: We have shown that our model can achieve high accuracy when it comes to predicting a future event triplet or the timing of the event. Here, we present two case studies to demonstrate the ability of the evolutionary knowledge network to guide superior transitive thinking across multiple relationships in the knowledge graphics of Croatia. CASE STUDY I: ENEMY'S FRIENDS IS AN ENEMYWe consider both cases as a test quadruplet (Istanbul, Fight, South Korea, 10 / 03 / 2015) Our model gives rank-1 to the object entity South Korea, while all other baselines do not predict well (rank > 250). The above test event is a new relationship and has never been seen in training. This case is interesting as there are at least 5 different entities in intertwined relationships that make a very challenging test case predictive. The story associated with the event involves an attack on South Korean people during a protest in Istanbul.

(Bordes et al., 2011) defines a score function as an L1 distance between two entity vectors projected into relationship space.

To alleviate memory complexity associated with that model, (Bordes et al., 2013) proposed TransE model that computes the score as a distance between relation-specific translations of entity embeddings.
(Wang et al., 2014) improved TransE by allowing entities to have relation specific distributed representations on a relation specific hyperplane where distance between them is computed.
TransR (Lin et al., 2015) extends this model to use separate semantic spaces for entities and relations and does translation in the relationship space.

metadata.abstractText: Knowledge Graphs are important tools to model multi-relational data that serves as information pool for various applications. Traditionally, these graphs are considered to be static in nature. However, recent availability of large scale event-based interaction data has given rise to dynamically evolving knowledge graphs that contain temporal information for each edge. Reasoning over time in such graphs is not yet well understood. In this paper, we present a novel deep evolutionary knowledge network architecture to learn entity embeddings that can dynamically and nonlinearly evolve over time. We further propose a multivariate point process framework to model the occurrence of a fact (edge) in continuous time. To facilitate temporal reasoning, the learned embeddings are used to compute relationship score that further parametrizes intensity function of the point process. We demonstrate improved performance over various existing relational learning models on two large scale real-world datasets. Further, our method effectively predicts occurrence or recurrence time of a fact which is novel compared to any prior reasoning approaches in multi-relational setting.
